figure_1.title: Fig 1. Major sources of information about skin cancer.

figure_2.title: Fig 2. Reasons for performing skin self-examination.

figure_3.title: Fig 3. Awareness of risk factors for skin cancer.

figure_4.title: Fig 4. Awareness of signs and symptoms associated with skin cancer.

figure_5.title: Fig 5. The barriers to skin cancer screening.

As shown in Fig 1, the most frequently reported information source was the internet (69.0%), followed by friends or relatives (49.9%), while medical school represented the least commonly reported source (12.1%).Fig 1.
Among those who did perform them, 31.3% cited early detection of skin cancer as their reason; while 15.3% stated that, a doctor recommended it (Fig 2).
Awareness of the risk factors for skin cancer is presented in Fig 3.
Open in a new tabAwareness of the signs and symptoms associated with skin cancer is displayed in Fig 4.

254 (27.5%)
205 (22.2%)

60 (6.5%)


Practice score [Median (IQR)]
41 (31–45)



Open in a new tabAs shown in Fig 5, the most frequently reported barriers to skin cancer screening were "lack of knowledge about skin cancer” (74.1%), “lack of awareness of the need for skin cancer screening” (72.2%), and “having no symptoms” (54.1%), while the least frequently reported barrier was “difficulty of getting a date to do skin cancer screening” (16.8%).

As shown in Fig 1, the most frequently reported information source was the internet (69.0%), followed by friends or relatives (49.9%), while medical school represented the least commonly reported source (12.1%).
Among those who did perform them, 31.3% cited early detection of skin cancer as their reason; while 15.3% stated that, a doctor recommended it (Fig 2).
Awareness of the risk factors for skin cancer is presented in Fig 3.
Awareness of the signs and symptoms associated with skin cancer is displayed in Fig 4.

As shown in Fig 5, the most frequently reported barriers to skin cancer screening were "lack of knowledge about skin cancer” (74.1%), “lack of awareness of the need for skin cancer screening” (72.2%), and “having no symptoms” (54.1%), while the least frequently reported barrier was “difficulty of getting a date to do skin cancer screening” (16.8%).
